instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..

threads.title: 820 3115 no power
threads.message: 820 3115, no power, mag safe stays green, no liquid damage. <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> votage jumps all over the place. PPBUS 12.59v.

threads.title: 820 3115 no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> stable?
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

Test the board alone, nothing connected, apart of magsafe.

threads.title: 820 3115 no power
threads.message: 2info, i guess I did not leave my probe on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> for long enough yesterday. It starts at the correct 5v then starts bouncing around after a few seconds, I also get that lightning bolt on my fluke on that particular rail. <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> also jump around.

threads.title: 820 3115 no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable?
Steady green light on magsafe?
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> stable too?
Try another charger also.

threads.title: 820 3115 no power
threads.message:
Same mistake with PPBUS, it fluctuates from 12.59-12.45v

VCORE has 0v

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> voltage jumps all over the place

Green light on charger flickers very fast

have tried multiple chargers

threads.title: 820 3115 no power
threads.message: Ok so this could be a lot of things. Resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>? Any liquid damage near BIOS, clock chip, SMC, etc? Check all rails for shorts?

threads.title: 820 3115 no power
threads.message:
John B, resistance between 17/18 is 3.1ohm, and I get 20.4ohm between 27/28.

SMC and SPI ROM look very clean

<CHIP>U2600</CHIP> looks okay how ever Y2605 does look like its been touched by some type of crap that I did not notice at first. 

I am about to start on a hunt for shorts.

threads.title: 820 3115 no power
threads.message: Ok inspect all traces from clock chip to Y2605. Also wouldn't hurt to replaced <CHIP>U2600</CHIP>. Let us know if you find any shorts a common one on these is the audio caps for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>

threads.title: 820 3115 no power
threads.message: You nailed it JohnB, <CAPACITOR>C6213</CAPACITOR> was short.
